Now to say attem, shellachem, lachem, ethchem, and mimmechem, when you should say atta, shellecha, lecha, othecha, and mimmecha: This were to say, you, or ye, of you, to you, you, from you, when you should say, thou, of thee, to thee, thee, and from thee: and this would be false Hebrew, and English both; and like unto their manner of speaking, that sayes you, of you, &c. when they should say thou, of thee, &c. But read on.

row.cell:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hem or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hemma

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lamo or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lahem

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ethem or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 otham

div.p: Now to wrest all these words abovesaid out of their proper place, and speak the plural when you should speak singular, would not this be the same in Nature, with speaking you to one man, which is to be used when more than one is spoken too.
Those that followes, are when a woman, or women, are spoken to, and of:

row.cell:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 atten or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 attena

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hen or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 henna

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 othan or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eth-hen

div.p:
Now to write, or speak all these words contrary to their own place, and to put the Plurall in the Singulars place, Would it not be like their sayings, that sayes you woman, of you woman, &c.) when they should say thou woman, of thee (women, &c ••
) What say you Schollars? will you snuff hereafter, if one say thou to a particular? you will not, will you?
Come Priests, read some of your Hebrew Nounes, (so called) which you have in your common Grammars.
This the Grammarians calls the Duall Number, which shews forth onely two by Nature.
Now to put jadajim for jad, were to put both the hands for one hand; Is this good Hebrew? you will come to the Singular language by the Rod, who would have the Plural for the Singular.
Now to put raghlajim for reghel, is to put feet, for a foot.

Now to say debharim for dabhar, is to put words for a word; and this is like unto the Priests Doctrine, that puts the Scriptures, which is the Words, for the WORD. Professors, and Schollars, and Teachers, read on:
Now to say Shophtim, Iudges, when you should say Shophet, a Iudge, Is this good Hebrew? is not this false? and to speak Plural, when you should speak Singular?

Therefore thou must read Shophtim, Iudges, and Shophet, a Iudge: But to say there are many Judges, when there is but one Judge, Would not these be looked upon as mad men? they could not perswade them, but they were many men, when there is but one, Thou, and is not You; and they cannot distinguish betwixt Iudges, and a Iudge: So not betwixt You, and Thou; Shophtim, and Shophet. Say on:

row.cell:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 shephatim, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 sh • phutim

div.p: And to put Shephutim Shephatim, in place of Sphephot, is to put Iudgemens, and Plagues, for a Iudgement, and a Plague; Is this good Hebrew? Is this good sence? Are not these SotHeads, and Giddy-Heads, that speaks thus, to put the Plural for the Singular. But read on.

row.cell:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 shekketz, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 shikkutz

div.p: Now to put shikkutzim for shekketz, or shikkutz, were to put abominations for abomination, were this good Hebrew? like as you Pr •• ests have put many men for one man: Plural for Singular.

row.cell: a burning, or a fiery Serpent

div.p: Now to say Seraphim, when you should say Saraph, this is to say, here are many Serpents, when there is but one Serpent; Is this good Hebrew, you that put Plural for Singular? Is not this like unto you, that have corrupted your own Mother Tongue? and the Corruption in you is offended, if it be not given. Read on:
Now to Say Banim, when they should say Ben, is not this to say You, when they should say Thou? and to say Sons, when its but a son.
Now to say Rashim, when you should say Rosb; this is to say Heads, when you should say a Head.

row.cell:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 arim, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ajarim

div.p: Now to say Arim, or Ajarim, when you should say Ir, here the man speaks non-sence, when he sayes Cities, when there is but one City; as they that say You, when they should say Thou; and speaks of many where there is but one; and so the world is bred, and trained np in Non-sence, which speaks Plurall, when they should Singular.
Come Doctors, Lawyers, Schollars, Scool-masters, come to that which is called the Verb.

Now to say pakedu, when you should say pakad, were to put plural for singular, and were not true Hebrew; and none sayes so but the Novices, and Ignorant and Vulgar, though they tell the people they are Schollars. Say on:

And to say pèkadtem, when you should say pakadta, that when you are speaking to one man, you are speaking to many; would this be good sense, or true Hebrew? and is not this non-sense in the eyes of people, and like mad-men? But read on:
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pakadti
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pakadnu
is is
I have visited; that is, one we have visited; that is, more than one

Now to say pakadnu, when you should say pakadti, Is not this foolishnesse? Is not this to speak we, when you should speak I? and is not this false Hebrew? and to say we have visited, when you should say I have visited, Is this to speak like men in their sences? is not this non-sence?
Now read the Feminine, (so called) that is, when a woman, or women are spoken to, or of.

Now to say pakedu, when you should say pakeda; this were to put many women for one woman: and to say you, or ye women have visited, for thou woman hast visited, Who would speak in this language that were in their wits, or sences either?

Come Priests and Schollars, who cries up your Learning so much; Is it not false Hebrew, to speak pakedu, when you should speak pakeda? were not this to speak you, when you should speak thou? and you women, when you should speak thou woman?

Now to say pekadten, when you should say pakadt, is to say you, or ye women have visited, when you should say, thou woman hast visited; and this is non-sence, and false Hebrew; and they that teach this, you, for thou, and cannot bear it, but they must have you for thou, Are these men of undeastanding? or the Vulgar, and Ignorant, Barbarous, and Brutish? Yes, they be so.
Read on, and see some more Examples about that you call your perfect Verb.
Now to say Niphkadtem, when you should say Niphkadta, this were to put plural for Singular. Read again:

row.cell: you, or ye have visited diligently

div.p: This is not true Hebrew, to say, You have visited diligently, when you should say, Thou bast visited diligently

row.cell: you, or ye have caused to visit

div.p: Now to say hiphkadtem for hiphkadta, were to put you for thou.

row.cell: thou (man) wast made to visit, or thou wast visited by another
you, or ye men were made to visit, or you, or ye were visited by another

div.p:
Now to say hophkadtem, when you should say hophkadta,
were to say, you, or ye, were made to visit, or were visited by another, when you should say, thou wast made to visit, or wast visited by another. Read on again,

row.cell: thou man hast visited thy self

div.p: Now for to say Hithpakkadtem, when you should say Hithpakkadta, were to say, you have visited your selves, when you should say, thou (man) hast visited by self; and this were false, for Hithpakkadta, is thou (man) hast visited thy self and Hithpakkadtem, is you, or ye (men) have visited your selves. Say on:

Now to say Lamedu, when they should say Lamad; is not this to say many learned, when but one learned, and to put plural for Singular.
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lamadta
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lemadtem
is is
thou (man) hast learned you, or ye (men) have learned

Now to say Lamadnu, when you should say Lamadti, this were say we (men) or we (women) have learned, when you should say, I man, or I woman have learned; for lamadti is I man or woman have learned, and Lamadn • ; is we men, or women have learned.
And to say Lemadten, when you should say Lamada, this is to say, (women) have learned, when but a woman hath learned.

Now to say Lamedu, when you should say Lameda, were to say, they women have learned, when you should say, she women hath learned; for Lameda, is she bath learned, and Lamedu, is they (men) or they women have learned.

Now to say Limdu, learn thou man, doth not this deserve the Rod? which Limdu, is learn you, or ye men, and Lemôd is learn thou man Singular, and to say you, when he should say thou, is this good sence? is this good Hebrew?
Now to say Lemôdena, when you should say Limdi, were to say, let many women learn, when they should say, let one woman learn. Read on:
Now to say Tishlachu, when you should say Tishlach, is to say many shall send, when you should say, one shall send.
Now to say Tishlachna, many women shall send, when they should say Tishlechi, which is, one woman shall send, that is not good Hebrew, for Tishlechi, is thou (woman) shall send.

Say on:
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jiphkod Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jiphkedu
is is
he shall visit they (men) shall visit

Now to say jiphkedu, when you should say, jiphkod, you put they, for he in so doing, and this is non-sense, out of sence.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tiphkod Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tiphkedu
is is
thou (man) shalt visit you, or ye shall visit
Now to say Tiphkedu, when you should say Tiphkod, is to say you, or ye men, when you should speak thou.

Look unto the English, and many others who have corrupted their own tongue. Read on:
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ephkod is I shall visit, when a (man) or (woman) are spoken of
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 niphkod is we shall visit, when (men) or (women) is spoken of

Now to say Niphkod, when you should say Ephkod, this is to say we, when you should say I, and this would be false Hebrew; for Ephkod, is I man; or I woman shall visit, and Niphkod, is we men, or we women shall visit.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tiphkod Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tiphkodena
is is
she shall visit they (women) shall visit

Now to say Tiphkodena, they (woman) shall visit, when you should say Tiphkod, she (woman) shall visit, this is to say, many shall visit, when but one shall visit.
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tiphkedi
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tiphkodena
is is
thou (woman) shalt visit you, or ye shall visit

Now to say Tiphkodena, when you should say Tiphkedi, were to say you, or ye, women shall visit, when you should say, thou woman shalt visit and such speaking is false Hebrew, and English both, for Tiphkedi, is thou (woman) shalt visit, and Tiphkodena, is you, or ye, (women) shall visit.

div.head: Now see some Scripture Examples in Hebrew, about Thou, and You.
div.p: JEphtha's Daughter, said thou, and thy, to her Father, and did not say you, to him, Judges 11. 36.

q.l: Va tomer elaiv abi phatsita et picha:

div.p:
Mark, its picha, not pichem; thy mouth, not your mouth: And its
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 meojebecha, thy enemies. Mark, its cha, not chem; thy enemies, not your enemies.
And Nathan thou'd David, 2 Sam, 1. 27. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 atta haish, thou the man: Here he sayes, not you the man, but atta haish, thou the man.

And Isaac, his servant, thou'd his Master, Genesis 24. ver. 5.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ashib et bincha. Mark, its bincha, thy Son, not binchem, your Son.

And again, he saith,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 asher jatsata, from which thou camest: Here its jatsata, not jetsatem; thou camest from, not you came from.

And Pharoab Thou'd Iacob, and said, How old art thou? Gen. 4 • 8. In the Hebrew, it's
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Camma •• jeme sh • ne • ajiecha: Mark again, its
• aji • cha, of thy life not hajiechem, your life.

And in the third verse, Pharaoh said unto Iosephs Brethren, What is your Occupation? Its 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ma • ashechem, your occupation, not thy occupation; its chem, not cha; your, not thy, when he speaks to more then one, but when he spoke to Iacob abovementioned, then he says, cha, not chem; thou, not you; and here when he speaks to Iacobs sonns, being more than one; he speaks plurally, and not singularly, chem, and not cha, you, and not thou. So let pharaoh, witness against you Priests, and Schollars in England, that makes no distinction when you speak to one, and when you speak to many, as hereafter in this BATTLE-DOOR, may plainly appear.

And Adam, thou'd God, Gen. 3. 9. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kolcha shama • ti: Here it's kolcha, not kolchem; thy voyce, not your voyce.
And God thee'd, and thou'd Adam, Gen. 3. 11. and said, who told thee, that thou waft naked: its lecha, to thee, not lachem, to you.

And God when he spoke to the Children of Israel, by the Prophet Ieremy, he you'd them, saying, Hearken not to the word of the Prophets, that Prophecy unto you, they make you vain, Ieremy 23. 16. its 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
lachem attechem: here is not lecha mentioned, when more than one is spoken to, but lachem to you, not lecha; to thee.

And so the Priests, and Schollars, and Doctors may see, that the Hebrew, they call the holy tongue, makes as plain a distinction when one is spoken to, and when more than one are spoken to, as any language that is.
div.trailer: The end of the HEBREW BATTLE-DOOR

div.head: THE CALDEE Battle-Door.
div.p: THe CALDEE Language, which teaches Thou and Thee to Singular, and You and Ye to Plural, though the Nations will hardly own it; either the French, Spanish, Italians, Greeks, or Latines, or English. But see some few Examples taken out of the Grammars, and Bible, as followeth:
But first read the Letters which are the same with the Hebrews Letters.

a b g d h v u z ch or hh t j i y
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
k or ch I m n s oo p ph or f
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ts tz or z q or k r sh th or t
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉

Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 àno or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 àno is
I (man) or (woman)
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 anan or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 anahhno or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nahhno is
we (men) or (women)
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 at or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ant is
thou (man) or masculine, so called)
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 antun or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 atun is you, or ye (men) or (males)
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hu or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hau or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jhu is
• e (male)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 himmon or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hinnun or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 innun is
they (males)
Now to say himmon, hinnun, jnnun; atun, antun; anan, nahhno, or ana •• no; this were to say they, you, or ye, and
• ree, when you should say he, thou, and I, and this were false Caldee, and English both. Now read those that are used, when a woman, or women, or f • eminines so called are spoken to or of.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 anti or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ant or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 at is
thou (female)
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 anten or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aten is
you, or ye (females)
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ihi or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hi is she
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 innen or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hinne •
is
they (females)
Now to say jnnen, hinnen, aten, anten, when you should say
at, ant, anti, and hi, jhi, this were to say, they (women) or ( f • emales) and ye, or you, (women) or (f • emales) when you should say, thou (woman) or female, and she (woman) or female: and this is to speak to many (women) or (females) when there is but one to speak to: but now read on to those which are called in the Caldee Grammars, the Inseparable Pronounes, and Affixes, or Suffixes, placed at the ends of words, and signifies as followeth.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 i 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ai 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ni or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nnani or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ano is
me, my, at the end of words
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 an 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ain or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 no or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nan is
us, our, at the end of words

Now to put an, ain, no, nan, when you should put i, ai, ni, nnani, or ano, this were to put us, our, when you should put me, my; and this would be false, and deserves the Rod.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 och or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 noch or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aik is
thee, thy, at the end of words, when a man, or a male is spoken to
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 cho ••
or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 cho ••
is
you, your, at the end of words, when men, or males are spoken to

Now to say chom, chon, when you should say, och, noch, aik, this were to say, you, your, when you should say, thee, thy; and this were to put many Men, or Males, for one Man, or one Male. But Say on:
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 o • i is
him, his, at the end of words; or this, or that Male, or Masculine (so called)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hi
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 neh
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hon is
them, their, or these, or those Males, or Masculines (so called)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hom
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nun

Now to say hon, hom, nun, when you should ohi, e • , hi, ne • , this were to say, them, their; or these, or those (males) or (masculines) when you should say, him, his; or this, or that (male) or (masculine;) and this would be false again, as all the rest before mentioned; and a grosse perverting of every word from its own proper signification, and contrary to Grammar directions; and Scripture Examples; Now come to those that are put at the end of words, when a woman, or women, or f • emales are spoken of or to.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ek is
Thee, Thy, at the end of words
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ki
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aik
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nek
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 chen or chen is You, Your

Now to put chen, when you should put ek, ki, aik, nek, is to put you, your; when you should put thee, thy; and this were false again. But Say on.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 oh is
her, at the end of words; or this, or that Feminine (so called)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ho
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 noh
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hen is
them, their; or these, or those Females, or Feminines (so called)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nan
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nin
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nen

Now to put, or place hen, nan, nin, nen, at the end of words, when you should put, or place; oh, ho, no • , this were to put them, their, or these or those females, or feminines, in place of her, or this, or that female, or feminine; and they that write or speak thus, must come and be taught this BATTLE-DOOR.

div.head: Read some Examples in that which is called the perfect Verb.
div.p: Now to say pkadu, and pkadtun, when you should say pkad • , and pkadt; this is to say, they, and you, have commanded, when they should say, he, and thou, hast commanded, and this is like the practise of the Nations, whose hand writing declares the contrary; So are come under the smart Rod.

Feminine, (so called) when a woman, or women, are spoken to or of.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pikdath is She (woman) hath Commanded
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pèkadt Thou (woman) hast Commanded
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pèkada is They (women) have Commanded
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pèkadten You, or Ye, (women) have Commanded

Now to say pèkada, and pèkadten; when you should say, pekadt, and pikdath, this were to say, you, or ye women, and they (women) have commanded, when you should say, Thou (woman) hast Commanded, and She (woman)
• ath Commanded: and this hath been the practice of the unlearned, (yet pretended learned) who speaks false Calde • , and English both, when a man, or woman, or men, or women speaketh of themselves.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pikdeth is
I (man) or (woman) have Commanded
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pekadna is
we (men) or (women) have Commanded
Now to say pekadna, when you should say pikdeth, is to say we men, or we women have commanded, when you should say, I (man) or I (women) have commanded; is not this false Caldee, and English both?

div.head: Now Read some Examples about those that are called the Nounes in the Caldee Grammars.

row.cell:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tur or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 turo

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 detur or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 deturo

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 letur or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 leturo

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jattur or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jatturo

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 mittur or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 mitturo

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 turin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ture or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 turaijo

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 deturin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 deturaijo or deture

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 leturin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 leture or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 leturaijo

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jatturrin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jatture or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jattuarijo
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 mitturin or mitture or mitturaijo

div.p:
Now to say turin, ture, turaijo, &c. when you should say tur, turo, &c. as above mentioned, this were to say mountaines, when you should say a mountaine, and this were false, for tur, or turo, is a mountaine, and turin, or ture, or taraijo, is mountaines. But Read on.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tzidqo or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tzidqetho is Righteo • snesse
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tzidqon or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tsidqotho is
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Righteo • snesses

Now to say tzidqotho, or tzidqon, when you should say tzid qo, or tzidqetho, this were to say, righteossness, for righteo • snesses.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 reglo or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 regel is a Foot
Dual that is, two
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 raglajin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 raglin is both the Feet

Now to say raglin, or raglajin, when you should say regel, or reglo, this were to say both the feet when there is but one foot.
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 jad or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ido is a Hand
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 idajin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
idin
is two Hands

Now to say jdajin, or jdin, when you should say jdo, or jad, this were to say, there were two hands, when there is but one hand; and this were false Caldee, and English both, for jad, or jdo, is one hand, and jdin, or jdajin, is two hands.

div.head: Now Read a few Scripture Examples in Caldee, about the Singular, and Plural Language.
div.p:
NEbuccadnezar the King, he said ye, to many, Daniel 2. 8. ye would gain the time in the Caldee, its 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
jdd • no antun tsabnin: Mark, its antun you, or ye, not ant, not at, which is thou, as is before expressed.

And in the nin • h verse, and ye have prepared lying, and corrupt words, it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hisdamnetun, &c. Mark, its
•• is
•••• etun, ye, or you, have prepared, not hisdamnet, thou hast prepared; here its Plural not Singular, when he speaks to the Caldeans, being more than one, but when he speaks to a particular, he sayes, art thou able to make known the dream, 26. verse, its 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bajthaik chahel, here you may see again, the ending is with the Singular, not with the Plural, aik, not chon, thou, not you, when one is spoken to.

And Daniels Answer, was thou to the King again, in the 31. verse, thou ô King sawest, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ant malko, hhaze havaita, here its ant, not antun, nor atun, which is you, or ye, as is before expressed.

And in the 37. verse,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ant malko melek
• alk •• jo, here you see again, its ant, not ant • n, thou ô King, not you, ô King, and the King was not offended at the word ant, which in English is thou. So by these few Examples you may plainely see a clear distinction, made in the Caldee Language, when one is spoken to, and when more then one is spoken to, and so throughout that Language, as in all other the Oriental Languages, there is a plain distinction, betwixt Singular and Plural, as in any Languages that are.

And so you Schollars, Doctors, that have boasted of the tongues, you may be a shamed for what you have spoken, and done this seaven years and more, against that harmless People called Quakers, for saying thou, to one, and you, to many Might not the King have said before mentioned, to them that spoke to him in the Singular Language, ant which is thou, what ant's thou me, as well as the proud Professors in this age have said, what thou's thou me, I will have atun, or antun, said to me, the King might say, which in English is you, or ye, as well as an English man may say, I will have you said to me, but we do not read that the King was offended, for any using the word at, or ant to him, which in English is thou.

div.head: Directions for pronouncing Hebrew and Caldee.
div.p: BEsides the 22 Letters in the BATTLE-DOOR, there are others Marks placed with them to sound them, which serve as Vowels, so called; whereof some are sounded long, and some short.

The long •
â • ê as êa, • î as îe, and •
ô as oa,
• û as 〈◊〉 in Root. the short are • and •
a, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 e, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 i. as i i in His, •
o, •
u, as u in Truth.

These are sounded after the Letters, to which they belong.
As 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
• hâ, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 bea, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈◊〉
• dhô, • û, as • ; • o 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pha, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pe. Except - under 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which - is read before those letters, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Eloah, God, not Eloha, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ruach, the spirit, not roocha
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Ies •• a, a Saviour, or Iesus; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Mashiach, anointed, M • ssiah, or Christ, not Mashich • :
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is by some sounded as g, by others as gn in the beginning and middle of words, and ng in the end: but the Iewes sound it not at all, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 they read it im, with, &c. Nalso hath no sound, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
abh, a Father; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 a man, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 not,
• hath no sound in the end, but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as gâlâ, he revealed,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈◊〉
with before it makes av, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈◊〉
meek: or with between them, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
de • harav, his words, not debaraiv▪ or with - as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kav, a measuring-line. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ev, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
peaceable.
• iv, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
piv, his mouth. If
• or • have under them another vowel, so called, then the (.) upon • is • , and • is v, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hô-vâ, calamity; and the (.) in • maketh double v, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kiv-vâ, he waited in hope.

is not sounded without a vowel, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ech, how; • dv, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 re, Except in the end after • or • as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 adhô-n • i, Lord; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
p • -nai, my face: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 gôi, a nation; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
gâ-lûi, revealed: with a vowel it is sounded as y, as
• yadh, a
• and.

marked on the left side is
• , and if there be no vowel under i • , the (.) is o, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
So-nê, • ating;
• marked on the right side is sh; and if the letter before it hath no vowel, then the (.) is ô, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Mô-s • ê, Moses: sometimes it hath two ( • ) as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Shô-chadh, a gift, reward, or bribe▪ and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Nô- se, he who lifteth up, or pardoneth.
o short, is often writ without (:) and then differs not in form from • â long, when yet it is short o, and is thus known:

1. Before (:) or (.) if no accent come between, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
zochra, she remembred: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ron-n • , sing ye.

2. before a letter having - after it, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ko • all, except 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
go before - as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
lâ, no; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 m •
what.

3. In the end of a word, beginning with! 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
• a, or ve, and- as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
vai-yakom, and be rose; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 veja-kom; and he shall arise.

4. before under 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or N as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 o-holô, his taber •• ole,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ho-omâdh, he is appointed, &c.

5. Before if follow it as, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
o-h • l-châ, thy tabernacle, &c.
(:) is sounded very short, oft-times not at all, but is silent, quiescent, or mute. Its Read.

1. In the beginning, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
be-yôm, in the day.
2. After a long vowel, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pâ̄-kedhû, they have visited.
3. After another (.) mute, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 yiph-kedhoû, they shall visite.

4. Under strong (.) as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dzammero • , sing ye; and under
a letter immediately doubled, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 halel • , praise ye.

Otherwise its not read, as I in the end, although two come together 1 2, after a short vowel: 3. before another (:) 4. after a long vowel, with a tonic accent, (so called) as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pekôdh-na, visit ye women.

(.) In a letter is sometimes milde, only takes away the (h) or aspiration from these • ix letters; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bh, gh, dh, ch, ph, th: so that with this (.) in them, they are written b, g, d, c, p, • ; sometimes (.) is of more force, and doubleth the letter, in which it is to avoid much writing, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pinna, a 〈◊〉 ; not phina: it is milde (onely in these fix letters, and that) onely in the beginning, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pe; a mo • th; not phe, nor ppe.

2. After (:) mute, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
tiz-ke, thou shalt be clean, or pure; not thizk-ke. It is strong, and doubles the letter after a short vowel in the midst of a word, and refers to two syllables at once; and the letter which lies hid in (.) hath alwayes belonging to it (:) mute, as of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
lâm-mâ, is made, and for shortnesle written
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
lâm-mâ, why.

It sometimes also doubles the first letter of a word, when the word before ends with 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 â 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
a, or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
e, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ma-t tô • h, how good! Or if the foregoing word ends with any of these terminations servile, without, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 â, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hâ, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tâ, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 kâ, or as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 kû-mû tz tzeû, arise depart;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ên yeshû-a-thâ 1 lô, there is no salvation for him.
It never is • ound in these 4 letters, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉

In 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (.) is • ound but onely at the end of a word, and notes that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is to be sounded, without which it is never sounded in the ends; as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ragh-lâh, her foot;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tô râ, the law, not thô-râh: Nota, This▪
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 kol-ish, every man. The Caldee hath the same pronunciation, save that (:) is not sounded, though after a long vowel, (so called) as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 she-eltâ, a petition: and that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
makes eu both in the end, and in the middle of a word: as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 heu-thâ, a beast; and ' makes ai in the middle, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kadh-majthâ, prima, first fem. and that they observe not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ni, as in Hebrew.

Is by some rendred o in Caldee, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 urcho, a way;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 huc-metho, Wisedome: so she-eltho, and heu-tho.
div.trailer: The End of the Caldee Battle-door.

div.head: THE SYRIACK BATTLE-DOOR.

row.cell: In the beginning of a word.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 B, or Bh, or u
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 G, or Gh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 D, or Dh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 K, c, or Ch
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Aa, or Oo
This letter 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is not expressed in sound in the Battle-Door, because the pronunciation of it is unknown to the Grammarians themselves.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 P, Ph, or F
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Ts, tz, z, ss
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Q, or K
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Th, or t

div.p:
The Syrian Language is thou to one, and you to many, Singular and Plural, in the Testament and Grammar; as may plainly appear here in this Battle door.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eno or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 no is I (man) or (woman)
Plurall
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hhnan or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nahhno is we (men) or (women)

Now to say hhnan, or nahhno, when you should say eno, or no, this were to say we, when you should say I, and this were to put Plural for Singular, for eno, or no is I; and hhnan, or nahhno is we.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 at is
thou (man)
Plurall
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 anthun or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 atun is you or ye (men)

Now to say anthun, or atun, when you should say at, this were to say you, or ye (men) when you should say, thou (man) and this were false Syriack, and English both, for this deserves the rod; for at, is thou (man) and at • n, or anthun, is you, or ye (men.)
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hu or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hau is he
Plurall
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 honun, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hen • l or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 enun is
they (men)

Now to say honun, or henun, or enun, when you should say, hu, or hau, this were to put they (men) for he (man) and this would be false Syriack, and English both; for honun, or henun, or enun, is they (men) and hau, or hu, is he (man;) but read on:
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ati or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 at is thou (woman)
Plurall
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aten is you, or ye (women)
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hi, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hoi is she, or it (female)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hai, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 he
Plurall
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 honen 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 henen or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 enen is they (women) these, or those (females)

Now to say aten, honen, henen, or enen, when ye should ati, or at, this were to say, you, or ye (women) and they (women) or these, or those (females) when you should say thou (woman) and she, or it (female.) And this were to say, there were many (women) or (females) when there is but one (woman) or one (female) and this would be false Syriack, and English both; for ati, or at, is thou (woman) and hi, or hoi, or hai, or he, is she, or it (female) and aten is you, or ye (women,) and honen, or henen, or enen, is they (women) or these, or those (females.) But come, read on,
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eno or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 no is I (man) or I (woman) or Male or Female
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hhnan, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nahhno is we (men) or (women) or (Males) or Females
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dil or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dili or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilai of me (man) or (woman)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilan, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilon of us
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 li or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lai to me
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lan or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lon to us
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lai or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 li me
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lan or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lon us
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 meni or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 men is from me (man) or woman
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menan from us

Now to say hhnan, or nahhno dilan, dil • n, lan, lon, lan, lon, and menan, when you should say eno, or no, dil, dili, dilai, li, lai, li • lai, and men, or meni, this were to say we; of us; to us; and from us; when you should say I; of me, to me, me, and from me, and this would be false Syriack, and English both; for eno, or no, is I; and
•• nan, or nahhno is we, dil, or dilai; or dili, is of me, and dilan, or dilon is of us, li, or lai, is to me, and lan, or lon, is to us, lai, or li is me, and lan or lon is us, men, or meni, is from me, and menan is from us
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 at is
thou (man) or (male)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 atun or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 anthun is you or ye men
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 diloch of thee
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilchun of you
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 loch, to thee
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lechun to you
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 loch thee
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lechun
you or ye (men) or males
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menoch from thee
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menchun from you

Now to say atun, or anthun, dilchun, lechun, and menchun, when you should say at, diloch, loch, loch, and menoch, this were to say you, or ye (Men) or Males, of you, to you, you, or ye (men) or males, and from you, when you should say thou (man) or (male) of thee, to thee, thee, and from thee, and this would be false Syriack and English both; and Contrary to the Examples above mentioned
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hau or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hu, is he
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 honun is they men
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dileh of him
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 henun or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 enun
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 leh, to him
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilhun, of them
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 leh, him
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lehun, to them
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 meneh, from him
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lehun or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 enun
them (Men) or (ma • es)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menhun from them

Now to write or speak any of these words above mentioned out of its proper place were the same in Nature and ground, with saying you when you should say thou. Now read on to those which are called the faeminine, when a woman, or (women) are spoken to or of,
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ati or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 at is
thou (woman) or (Female)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilech or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilechi of thee
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lech or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lechi, to thee,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lech or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lechi thee,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menech or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 mennechi from me • ,
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aten is
you, or ye women
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilchen, of you
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lechen, to you
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lechen
you, or ye
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menchen from you
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hi, is
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 honen is they (Females)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hoi,
she, or it (female)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 henen or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 enen
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hai or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 he
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dilhen of them
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 diloh of her, or of it
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lehen to them
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 loh to her, or to it her, or it (female)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lehen them, or those (Females)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 loh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menhen or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menhen from them
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menoh from her, or from it

Now to say honen, henen, or enen, dilhen, leben, lehen, and menhen, when you should say hi, hoi, hai, or he, diloh, loh, loh, and menoh,
this were to say they (women) of them, to them, them, and from them, when you should say she or it, of her or of it, or to it, her, or it; and from her or from it female. And this manner of speaking would be a grosse perverting of words from their proper Signification, like unto the Priests and Doctors, and Scholars and Professors that sayes you to one, when they should say thou.

Now come read those that are called the Inseparable pronouns
〈◊〉 , or affixes, or suffixes placed at the end of words, and signifies as followeth;
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 i, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ai, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ni, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ini, being placed at the end of words, when a man or (male) speaketh of himself; or a (woman) or female speaketh of her self, is me, my, myne;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 an 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ain, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
nan at the end of words is us, our ours when men or women, Males or Females speaketh of themselves.

Now to put an, ain, and nan, when you should put i, ai, ni, and ini, this were to put us, our, and ours; in place of me, my, myne, and this would be false Syriack and non-sence, and the least child that hath but read the first Rudiments in Syriack would laugh at you, if you should thus pervert words Contrary to Grammar rules, and Scripture Examples in the Bible;
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
och or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ok,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
aik, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
nok these at the end of words is thee, thy, thine, when a man, or a male is spoken to,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
chun
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
aikun, is, you, your, yours, when (men) or, males are spoken to,

Now to say chun, aikun, when you should say ocb, ok, aik, or nok, this were to say you, your, and yours, when you should say, thee, thy, and thine, and this would be false again; but read on,
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eh 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 au, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 oi, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 neh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hun, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aihun, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nun
is is
him, his, at the end of words them, their

Now to put or place hun, aihun, nun, when you should put eh, au, oi, neh, this were to put them, their, in place of him, his; Now read those that are used at the end of words, when a woman, or women, or the feminine so called are spoken to, and of
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ech or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ek and
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aik is thee, thy, &c.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 chen or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ken and
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aiken is you, your, &c.

Now to put chen or ken and aiken when you should put ech, or ek, and aik, were to put you, your, in place of thee, thy, and this were to speak to many women or females where there is but one woman or female to speak to
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 oh, is
her, or hers, or it, or this or that female, or feminine so called
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hen, is at the end of words is them, their, or these or those (females)
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eh and
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 noh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 enen
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 aihen,

Now, to put hen, enen, and aihen in place of oh, eh, and noh, this were to put them, their, or these or those females, in place of her, hers, or it, or this or that female, and such Syriack and English both deserves the rod and must be brought to read this Battle-Door; Now come and see some of those words that are called Nouns in the Common Grammars,
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 melek or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 malko is a king
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dmelek, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dmalko, of a king
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lmelek, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lmalko to a king
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lmelek, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lmalko the king
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menmelek or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 menmalko from a king
Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 malkin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 malke, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 malko or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 malkai is of kings, and so adding the letter 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
l, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
men, as is above mentioned in the Singular, to every word of the Plural, it will be lmalkin, lmalke, lmalko, lmalkai, is to kings, or the kings, and menmalkin, menmalke, menmalko, and menmalkai is from kings;
any of these words is for kings
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dmalkin
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 dmalke, &c.

Now to say malkin, malke, malko, malkai, dmalkin, dmalke, dma • ko, dmalkai, lmalkin, lmalke, lmalko, l • malkai, and menmalkin, menmalke, menmalko and menmalkai, when you should say malek, malko; dmelek,
d • malko; lmelek, lmalko, and menmelek, or menmalko; this were to say kings, of kings, to kings, the kings, and from kings, when you should say a king, of a king, to a king, the king, and from a king; and this would be false and contrary to Grammar directions,
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 zedqo or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 zedqtho is Righteousnesse
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 zedqon, or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 zedqotho is Righteousnesses;

Now to put zedqon, or zedqotho instead of zedqo, or zedqtho were to put Righteousnesses for Righteousness, and this were to put Plural for Singular like them, that puts you for thou▪ But read on,
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 gabhro or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 gèbhar is a man
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 gabhrin or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 gabhre or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 gabhrai is men

Now to say gabhrai, gabhre, or gabhrin, when you should say gèbhar or gabhro, this were to say men, when there is but a man; And this were non-sence, and they that speak thus are more like mad men, than men in their sences.
Singular
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 abo, is a father Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 abohe or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 abohotho is fathers

Now to say abohe, or abohotho, when you should say abo, this were to put fathers for a father, and this would be false; for abo is a father, and obohe or abohotho is fathers. Come you that will not have one say thou to a particular, but you, and will make no diftinction in your practice, betwixt you and thou, Plural and Singular, read on in some few Examples, in that which is called the perfect verb.
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkadt
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkadtún,
is is
thou (man) hast Commanded
you or ye have Commanded,
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkudh
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkudù
is or without the laft letter ù, sounded pkud is Command you or ye (man)
Command thou (man) or (male)
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 tephkudh is thou (man) shalt or wilt Commaud,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
tephkdun is you or ye men shall or wil Command.

Now to say pkadtun, pkudù, or pkud, and tephkdun, when you should say pkadt, pkudh, and taphkudh, this is to say you, and ye (men) have Commanded, Commaund you or ye (men) and you or ye shall or will Commaund; when you should say thou (man) hast Commanded, Commaund thou (man) or (male) and thou man shalt or wilt Command, and this manner of writing and speaking both would be hist at in every Scool that learns the Syrian Language, and would be Contrary to all Writers of Grammar in that Tongue, and Contrary to Scripture Examples; but before you come to Scripture Examples, read a little more about thou and you, in that word above mentioned, when a (woman) or female or women, or females are spoken to and of.
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkadt is thou (woman) or female hast Commanded;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkadten is you or ye women have Commanded;
Singular Plural
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
tephkdin is thou (woman) or (female) shalt or wilt Command,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
tephkdon is you or ye women, or females shall or will Commaund:

Now to say pkadten, and tephkdon, when you should say pkadt, and tephkdin, this were to say you or ye (women) or females have Commanded, and you and ye (women) or females shall or will Command, when you should say thou (woman) or (female) hast Commanded, and thou (woman) or female shalt or wilt Command, and this manner of writing or speaking is like them that sayes you to one woman, when they should say thou.
Now see a few Scriptures Examples in the Syrian Language, about thou and thee, and you or ye, Plural and Singular.

David Thou'd God, and said thee and thou, and thy to him, as you may read in the Psalms all along, but see an Example or two in the Syrian Language,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
umen karso dem aloh • at lo tharhhek men.
In Latine it is, & a ventre matris meae Deus meus tu ne absis a me: In English, and thou my God from my Mothers Belly, be not thou absent from me, psal. 22. Mark its 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
at, thou, not atun, you;

And in the ninth Psalm, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
wansabhrun boch cul jodeai shemoch, in the Latine its, & sperabunt in te omnes Scientes nomen tuum: in English it is, and all that know thy name will hope in thee.
Mind again, shèmoch thy name, not shèmchun your name, and boch, not bèchun in thee, not in you.

Christ when he spoke to the Scribes and Pharisees, being more than one, he speaks Plurally, when he said woe to you, in the Syriack it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
woi lechun, woe to you, not woi loch, not woe to thee, they being more than one, Matth. 23. But when Christ spoke to the high Priest, being but one Priest, not many, he thou'd him, Matth. 26. in the Syriack, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
at emart, thou hast said it, here its at thou, not atun you.

And Iohn writing to the Saints you's them, saying in Syriack, 1 Ep. Iohn 1. v. 20.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Watun meshichuto it lechun men kadisho uforshin atun & lechul nosh. That is, And ye have an unction from the holy one, and ye discern every man. Here its atun ye, not at thou, when he writes to more than one.

Felix theed Paul, Acts 24, 25. I will send to thee Mittam ad te, in the Syriack, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
eshadar bothroch, mark its och, not chun, thee, not you: And Paul thou'd Faelix in the same Chapter; forasmuch as I do know that thou hast been of many years a Judg of this Nation, &c. and because thou maist understand, &c. In the Syriack,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
men shnaio saghiotho joda no dithaik dajono damo hono, mark its dithaik, here is aik which at the end of a word is thee, or thy, not aikun, you nor your, in the Latine version as you call it, its, a multis annis scio te esse judicem hujus gentis; in English its from or of many years: I know thee to be a judg of this Nation.

And because thou maist understand, &c.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
chad meshbach at lmeda, mark again, its at, not atun, thou, not you: in the Latine, Quum tu possis nosse, &c. that thou maist know, &c.

And in the same 24 Chapter, Tertullus a certain Oratour, thou'd and theed and thy'd Faelix the Governor, seven or eight times in the beginning of that Chapter, and we do not read that the Governor was offended for using the Singular Language, you will not say that Tertullus was ill-bred, he was a Rhetorician, he knew fine speaking; he knew how to affect the Governor with his adorned speech, and yet he uses the Singular Language to him; as you may read in his Speech to him, in the beginning of that Chapter, and any that knowes the Syriack Tongue, may see that there is no mention of you, ye, nor your, but thou, thee, and thy,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
mettulthoch for thy sake, mark its och, not chun, thy, not your: And so seven or eight times, or more, there is och, ech, and aik, and at, used by the Orator to the Governor, which in English as before mentioned is thou, thee, thy, and not chun, aikun, nor chen, nor aiken, which at the end of words is thee, thy, thine, nor atun, which is you, or ye, and so all along throughout the Testament in the Syrian Language, the Singular tearms are used to the Singular, and Plural to the Plural, not like the Scholars and Teachers of England and elsewhere in most parts in Christendome, who are degenerated from the propriety of their own Language, and will not practice what they teach in their Grammars, nor what is written in the Scriptures of truth, and many more places I might instance, that the Syriack Language, which the Scholars sayes was Christs Language, is as punctuall and as clear in making a distinction, in this patticular, betwixt Singular and Plural, as any Language, though the Teachers in England makes none in their practice, who will say you to one man, and you to more than one, but sure this that already hath been said about it, may be sufficient to convince them about it, or at least to stop their fretting against any for saying thou to one man, which is the propriety of the English Tongue, and not you to one.

div.head: Some Directions for the Reading or Sounding Syriack.
div.p:
Besides the two and twenty Letters mentioned in the Battle-Door there are other Letters joyned, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
a l
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
la
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 that is
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . And ll at the end thus 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; and where l
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ends a word, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 begins the next, they are oft joyned thus 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
al-estho, upon the wall.

These six Letters are written with a point upon them, and are read,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
b,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
g,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
d,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
k,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
p,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
t, but with the point under them
are read, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bh or v,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
gh,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
dh,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ch,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ph, or f, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
th.

div.head: Divers Letters are founded otherwise than they are written, viz.
div.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 after another 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is read j or y, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , ojar the ayre. Also in the participle of the Present-tence of Verbs haveing 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , u, silent in the middle as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kojem standing. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
z before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
th, or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ch or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
k, is sounded as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
s. as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
gestho, Wooll, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
s before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
g or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
d, is sounded as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
z, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hhezdo, reproach: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
g before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
th is sounded as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
k, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
rektho, desire.

The Vowels (so called) are as followeth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is a, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ba,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is e, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
be,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is i, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bi,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is o, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , bo.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is u, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bu. Note the marks are placed above or beneath according to convenience, but the points are alwaies placed as abovesaid. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is au,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is au,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is eu,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is iu,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is ou,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is oi, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 makes ai.

div.head: Divers Letters are written and not sounded, as
div.p:
1. All Letters having a stroak under them, and so are oft times left quite out, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
barnosho, the son of man, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ezath, he went, &c, except in the Impèrative Mood passive, where the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 onely notes the Letter under which it is to want a Vowel, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ethpaqd, be thou commanded.

2. Neither 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nor 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 have properly any sound but as they are pointed, or marked, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
aloho, God,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
• had, be remembred.

3. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
i having 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 under it, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ileph, not jileph, he hath learned not. 2. before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
golen, not golein, they revealed. 3. In the affixes as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
aloh my God, not alohi, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 not meni but men, from me. 4. nor in the feminine termination of Verbs (so called) as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkad, they women commanded, 5. nor in these words, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
mnothmol, the day before yesterday,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ethmol, yesterday, &c. in breif 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is never sounded at
the end of a word if it hath no Vowel belonging to it.

4. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is not sounded in 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 joyned after another word, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
tob-u, he is good, although it hath no stroake under it, as it ost hath, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hu- • , he is,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is not at all sounded, neither the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
nor the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 joyned after Nowns or Verbs (so called) as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
not malkau-i nor malkau-hi, his kings, but malkau and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
anoi respondit • i, be answered him,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kroi, vocavit eum, he called him.

5. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
v, is not sounded in the middle nor end after 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
malkutho or malku, a kingdome, nor after 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in forrein words, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
paulos, Paul, nor in the termination of any Verb, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
e • hal, they have eaten, not echalu.

6. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
d in these kind of words is not sounded, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ito, an assembly.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hhatho new masc. Except
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hhdhat
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , new fem.

7. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
n in these kind of words is not sounded, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
shato, a year,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
mdhito, a City:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
sphito, an ark or sbip, and some give this rule, viz. that 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
t, having 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 belonging to the foregoing Letter is not sounded; but 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
th is sounded as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kantho, a Companion or Fellow-servant: also in these words, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is not read, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
gaboro a Giant,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ghev, the side of a thing,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
alghev tturo, upon the side of the Mountain.

This point (.) is used above and beneath Letters, first to distinguish betwixt ambiguous words, and upon a Letter its put for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and beneath a Letter for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
idho, a hand, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
aidho, quae which feminine, so 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hu, himselfe, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hau, he,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
hi, her self, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , hoi, she,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
honun, they men, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
henun, themselves men,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
honen, they women,
from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
henen, themselves women:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
man, who, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
men, of or from, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bisho, evill, fom 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
boisho, wretched,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
avdo, a servant, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
abodho, a work,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
oulo, an infant, from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
aulo (without a point) iniquity, and from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
avolo (with the point above) wicked.
2. This Point serves to signifie the Moods and Tenses in Verbs so call'd.

1. Under a Letter it is a note of the Preter tense in all the Persons of it, except the first and third feminine, singular. 2. Its a note of the Imperative and Infinitive Mood. 3. It denotes all the persons in the future tense, except the first, singular and Plural: as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ebne, I shall build, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
nebne, we shall build, which is so distinguished from the third Person singular, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
nebne, he shall build.

This point (.) 〈◊〉 a Letter denotes 1. the first Person singular of the Preter tense, 2. the Participle of the Present tense, and there it serves for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , 〈◊〉 , in the first second and fifth conjugations, and in the third, and the first kind of the fourth conjugation it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
a 3. Its a note of the first Person in both numbers of the Future tense as abovesaid: And the third Person singular feminine, hath amongst some, one point at the end behind the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and one under the word, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
emrath, she hath said; among others, it hath two points underneath, thus, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
shroth, she hath loosed.

Two points upon a Letter is a note of the plural number in Nowns or Verbs (so called) as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
malke, kings,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkadh, or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
pkaden, they women have Commanded.

This stroak (-) is oft times upon Letters, 1. when the Letters serve as numbers, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 1, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 2, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 3, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 10, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 12, &c. 2. To shew that the word is writ short, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kadisho, holy. 3. Upon the Vocative Participle 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , O, to distinguish it from 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
au, or.

The pauses are, ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for;) ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for:) two points so 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for ( ) a parenthesis, three points thus ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for?) ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 for.)

div.head: THE ARABICK BATTLE-DOOR.

argument.p: The Arabians have in their Language proper distinctions betwixt the Singular, Duall, and Plural Numbers, so called, and when they speak of one, they use the Singular Number, and the Duall speaks of two, and the Plural speaks of more than two; as may be seen by these following Examples taken out of the Arabick Grammars, and Scriptures.

div.p: But first see their Letters, which in number are twenty eight, as followeth.

row.cell: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 —as the Hebrew 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉

Their Vowels are placed some above, and some beneath the other Letters thus, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 above a Letter is a, or e, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is ba, be,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 under a Letter is
•
as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
is bl
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon a Letter is • , or • , as,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is bo, or bu.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 T. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in the end is t.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 G or J, for so it is sounded.

This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon a Letter before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 having no Vowel is â.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
b â, This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 under, before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 without a Vowel is • long, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
is

bâ. These 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or above is an, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is ban. These 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
or • under is in, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is bin. These 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 above is on, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is bon. Note, This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 above is a, and this 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
o, alwaies upon the last Letters of words, and upon these Letters,

hh,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
th,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
s,

d, t.

• ,

• ,

g, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
k.

men, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kum.

as the Hebrew 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
d before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
it is not founded. This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon a Letter doubles it; except the same letter goes before it with this 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon it.
also 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before a, o, u.

〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before a Letter with 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon it, is not founded, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
errabbo, not elrabbo, the Lord.

b, is founded as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
m, before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ll,

div.p:
Severall Letters are joyned together, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , l and a joyned together, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is

is b & hh, and with a point upon the 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 thus 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 it is b & ch, &c. as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
n and ch, and so there are divers other Letters joyned together which are difficult, and too long to insert here.

cell.note: Sound the g, not as in English, but as z, y, as Rez-yolon, and Rez-yolin, as the french g▪ &c.

row.cell: Of a man, and to a man.

div.p: Now to say Regolâni, or Rigâlon, when you should say Regolon, this were to say two men, or more than two men, when you should say a man, for Regolon is a man, and Regolâni is two men, and Rigalon is men, more than two. Now is not this to put the Plurall or Duall for the Singular? is this good Arabick?

cell.note:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
n before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
t, &c. is founded as ng, so its angta, not an • a, &c.

row.cell: This • upon a Letter hath no sound (onely shews that that Letter is to be joyned in spelling, with the fore-going mark, as nahh-no, not nahhno, &c.

div.p:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
t,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
m, &c. is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 most commonly.

row.cell:
This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 adds nothing to the sound; and is o • t placed for
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in the beginning, end, and middle. And upon 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 it it notes them to be put instead of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉

cell.note: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon a Letter doubles it.

div.p: Now to put Angtumâ, Humâ, Angtum, Angtunna, Hum, or Hunna, when you should say Angta, Angti, Howa or H • a. This were to say ye two, they two men or women, ye men, ye women, they men, or they women, when you should say thou man, thou woman, he or she. Is this good Arabick thus, to confound the Duall and Plurall with the Singular?
Again to put Nahh • no for Anâ, is not this to say We for I? Is this good Arabick or English, to put the Plurall for the Singular?
Here followes some Examples of the Affixes (so called) that is words affixed or joyned at the end of other words, which are and do signifie as followeth.

cell.note:
Note these Affixes signify mine, thine, his, hers, your, their, when they are joyned to Nowns so called; as of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
meliko, a king is made▪
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
melkî, my king,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
melkuka, thy King, speaking to a man, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 melkuki, thy King▪ speaking to a woman▪
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 melkuho, his King. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
melkuhâ, her King. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 melkuna, our King. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , melkukum, your (of men) king. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 melkukunna, your (of women) King. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 melkuhum, their (of men) King.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 melkuhunna, their King, speaking of women, but when they are joyned to Verbs so called, they signifie thee, him, her, us, you, they, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Angsurka, I shall help thee, and
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Ansurkum, I shall help you, &c. Now is this good Arabick or good English, to say melkukum, your King, when you should say melkuka, thy King, or ansurkum, I will help you, when you should say ansurka, I will help thee?

div.p: Now to say hum, or hunna, when you should say ho or hâ, & kum and kunna when you should say ka or ki, and nâ when you should say î or ni, this were to say theirs, or them, when you should say his, or hers, or him, or her, and yours or you; when you should say thine, or thee; and ours, or us, when you should say mine or me: Is this good Arabick, or good English, answer you Doctors, Scholars, Priests, and Professors, that say you to one, when you should say thou.

row.cell: I man or woman have helped.
Ye two men or women have heped.
We have helped; more than two.
Ye men, more than two, have heped.
Ye women, more than two, have helped.
They men, more than two, have helped.
They women, more than two, have helped.

div.p: Now to say Nasartumâ, Nasarâ, Nasaratâ, instead of Nasarta Nasarti, Nasara, Nasarat, this is to say ye two have helped▪ they two men have helped, they two women have helped, when you should say▪ thou hast helped, he hath helped, or she hath helped, is this good Arabick (answer ye Dostors, Schollars, Priests and Professors) to speak in the Duall number, so called, when you should speak in the Singular? And wherefore serves the distinction of numbers, if they may be thus confounded?

Again to say Nasarnâ, Nasartum, Nasartunna, Nasarou, Nasarna, when you should say Nasarto, Nasarta, Nasarti, Nasara, Nasarat; is this good Arabick? is not this to say we, ye, they, more than two, men or women, have helped, when you should say I have, • hou hast, He or she hath helped; is this good English? answer ye that say you to one? or is it true to say that divers have helped? when but one hath helped? and do ye not speak thus, when you say you have to one, instead of thou hast? Consider.

div.head: Here follow some Scripture Examples concerning Thee and Thou, shewing that it is the Language which is onely us'd throughout the Scriptures, the Singular to One, and Plurall alwaies to many.
div.p:
Peter Thee'd Jesus, 17 Matth. 4. verse, and said unto him,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Iâ Rabbo geijidon lanâ én nekoúna hâhumâ * eteshâo an nésnahha háhunâ thélatha medâlin wâhhídatan láka wawâhhídatan limousei wawâhhídatan liîlijá * That is
Oh Lord it is good for us to be here: Wilt thou that we make here three Tabernacles: one for Thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elias?

Here when Peter speaketh of them all, he speaketh in the Plurall number; Iâ Rábbo geijidon lanâ, &c. oh Lord it is good for us, &c. lanâ is us, the Plurall Number. But when he speaks to Christ alone, he speaks in the Singular number; eteshâo an nésnahha hâhunâ thélatha medâ • in wâhhídatan láka, &c. That is, Wilt thou that we make here three Tabernacles, one for thee, &c. it is láka for thee, not
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
(for you) in the Plurall number, when he speaketh to one onely, although to Jesus his Lord, and our.

So Jesus when he spak to one woman thou'd her 15 Mat. 28.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Iâ merâto adîmon îmânuki jekóuno láki kâa áradti. That is, Oh woman great is thy faith, be it unto thee, as thou wilt, here it is îmânuki▪ thy faith, and jekoúno láki, be it unto thee▪ with the female affixe Singular, so called, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ki, thee or thy for a woman, not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
îmânukunna, nor 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
lákunna,
your faith, nor to you in the feminine affixe Plurall, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kúnna, your or you for women, as you may see above in the Affixes. Nor is it 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
kâa aradtunna, as you will, in the ending of the second person plurall, but kâa áradti, as thou wilt in the second person Singular feminine.

Paul thou'd King Agrippa, 26. Acts 27.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
eijuhâ-lméliko, agrîbbâ amâ tuséddiko-lenbijâo * anâ âalemo enneka tuseddíkuhum. That is,
Oh King Agrippa, dost thou not believe the Prophets? I know that thou believest them.
Here i • is tusêddiko, dost thou believe? in the second person singular, not tuseddikoûna, do you believe? in the second person plurall.

And Christ thou'd Paul, 22. Asts 7. verse, and said •
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Shâolo Shâolo líma tedtahíduni. That is, S • ul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?

And Paul thou'd Christ again, Acts 22. v. 8. •
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
fâ • jabto, anâ * jâ ábbo men ángta * That is,

I answered, Lord who art Thou? Here it is, men ángta, who thou? not
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
▪ men, ángtum who you?

And Jesus answered him, in the same verse again.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
•
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
fakâla lî* Anâ h • wa jesouhho-lnnâ sirîjo-lladî ángta tadtahídoho* That is; He said unto me; I am Iesu • of Nazareth
whom thou persecutest. Here it is all in the Singular number; again, it is fakâla l • , he said unto me, not
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 lanâ, unto us, and anâ, &c. I am Jesus, &c. not we are Jesus of Nazareth, and lladî angta, &c. whom thou, &c. not lladî angtum, &c. whom you persecute. Thus speaking to one they spake in the Singular number, but speaking to more than one they alwayes spake in the Plurall number.

Thus Peter, Acts 2, verse 14. said you to many.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 *
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 * 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉

fanáhada bítruso m • a • lâhhadi âshera * waráfaa sáutoho wachâtabahum kââlen * eijuhâ-rrigâlo-ljehóudo wâlkâtiboúna uresha • îma agjmaoúna fáljecun hâdhâ índekum maroúfán • wâangtitoú ílei ekwâilei * ílenna hâolâo léisou sekârei káma dánangtum ángtum * ilánnahâ-lssâato-ltháltheto mina-lnnehâri * That is,

But Peter stood up with the eleven, and lifting up his voice, spake unto them, saying; O ye men Jewes, and all ye that dwell in Ierusalem, be this known unto you, and he arken unto my words, Ver. 15▪ For these are not drunken as ye suppose, seeing it is but the third houre of the day.

Here he saith hâdhâ indekum maroúfân * be this known unto you▪ índekum, not in the singular number, índeka, unto thee, and káma dánangtum ángtum, as ye suppose, not káma dánangta angta; in the Singular, as thou supposest, but as ye suppose, &c.

So
• tephen speaking to the Jews you'd them▪ Acts 7. 51.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 *
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
féangtum tukâwimoúna roúhha • lkúdusiââman dféangtum nedîro abââkum. That is,
Ye resist the holy Spirit alwayes; for ye are like your Fathers. Here is again ángtum, not ángta; ye, not thou; and abâ • kum, your fathers; not abââka, thy fathers. &c.

Thus Christ also you'd the Scribes and Pharisees.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 * élweil • lákum eijub • -lketabato walfarrîsîjouna-lmerâouna ilánnakum▪ &c. That is,
Woe unto ye Scribes and Pharisees Hypocrites. because ye, &c. Here again it is not láka, nor illánnaka, (in the Singular) to thee▪ and because thou.

Christ you'd his Disciples Matth. 23. 8.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 *
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
fâémma ángtum fla tedóu lakum muállimâ álei-lárs fâinna muallímakum wâhh • don hówa-lmélihho wâangtum gjamîâ ichw • ton* That is,
But be ye not called Master upon Earth, for one is your Master even Christ, and all ye are Brethren.

And when Paul writes to the Saints he you'd them, 1 Cor.
• . • . * 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ním • ton lékum w • sel • meton m • na • lílahi ab • nâ w • rrabbi jes • úhhalmesíhhi *

Grace be unto you, and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. Here again it is all in the Plurall number, and not in Singular, but when they speak to one alone; so are not you Doctors, Schollers, Priests, and Professors, degenerated both from your own Mother Tongue, and from all the Learned Tongues so called, who say you to one?

Note the Arabians have no Accent, but it is observed that the first Syllable in words of two Syllables is sounded most, and the last Syllable, save two in words of many Syllables, unless the last Syllable save one hath one of these long marks, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
â,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
î

div.head: THE PERSIAN BATTLE-DOOR.

argument.p: In the Persian Language there is also a distinction betwixt the Singular and the Plurall Number, as may be seen in the Persian Grammar, where 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Tou is put for Thou, and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 shuma, for ye.

table.head: The Persian Alphabet or Letters are 32 in Number viz.

row.cell: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 —as in the Arabick.

The Vowels (so called) This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon a Letter is a, or e, as,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ba▪ or be. This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 under a Letter is i, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bi▪ and sometimes short e. This upon a Letter is o or u, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
bo or bu.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 G. as the French g.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Ch. as in Engl.

this 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is â, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
yâr, a Companio • , but if 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
• m, or 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
n, followes
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
▪ then this 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is sounded as o, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
adamion, men, and sometimes this 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 being placed in stead of
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
osmo •• heavek, This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is î or ie, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
tiz, sharp,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
sûârie, a riding. This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 before 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is ou, or û long, sounded as oo, in English, as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
ghoush (or ghoosh) an eare, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 zûr, • iolence. This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon these three Letters
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 notes that that Letter hath no vowell, but is to be joyned in sound with the foregoing, as
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
dànis-ten, to know. This 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 upon a Letter doubles it, as in the Arabick. In speaking, the Persians do o • t found more Lètters then they write; as, for

Mader Man, My Mother, they say, Madere Man. And for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Hâl chûb darem, I am in

div.p:
First see an Example in their first Declension (so called) which ends in 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
on in the Plurall number.

row.cell: A, or the Father, and of a Father.
To a Father, and the Father.
The Fathers, and of the Fathers.
To the Fathers, and the Fathers.

div.p:
Read on an Example in their second Declension (so called) which ends in 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
h â, in the Plurall number.

row.cell: The Heaven, and of the Heaven.
To the Heaven, and the Heaven.
I, and of me, or my.
We, and of us, or our.
Thou, and of thee, and thy.
Ye, and of you, or your.
He, and of him, or his.

div.p: Now to say shumâ, or shumârâ in Persian, when you should say, Tou or Tourâ: This is as the Professors and Schollers in England who say you, and your, when they should say thee and thine, or thy; and this is both false Pe • sick and false English, contrary to the Grammar Rules.

The Persians have no particular words to signifie my, thy, his, our, your, their by, and so they put the foregoing words, I, thou, he, we, ye, they, after words, as,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Pade • man, is my Father, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Pader • tou, is thy Father, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Pader • ou, is his Father, and so Pader-mâ is our Father, Pader-shumâ is your Father, and Pader-ishon is their Father, and so paderâ merâ, paderâ-mârâ, &c.
See here again an Example of the Verb (so called.)
